Expectation1: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation1: A contested motion is scheduled soon, and the client relies on effective advocacy to preserve their position.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: I sat at my desk, legal briefs spread before me, the clock ticking down to the contested motion I was scheduled to argue in court. My client’s case was hanging by a thread, and I knew how much depended on my preparation and presence. Every detail mattered; I owed them my sharpest advocacy. Just as I was reviewing my notes, my phone buzzed—a message from Brother Yusuf, a long-time congregant. He sounded desperate, asking if I could meet him soon. His family was in crisis, and he needed my guidance as his imam, someone to listen and help him find peace. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My client’s future, my congregant’s pain—both urgent, both deserving. I could not be in two places at once, and the expectations from each role clashed inside me. My mind raced, heart heavy, as I tried to figure out how to honor my responsibilities without failing someone who trusted me.
